revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=November 2010}} {{Split-apart|date=October 2012}} The term '''Junge Wilde''' ([[German language|German]] for "wild youth") was originally applied to trends within the art world,<ref Name="Fraser&Hoffmann">{{cite book |title=Pop culture Germany!: media, arts, and lifestyle |last=Fraser & Hoffmann |first= |authorlink= |coauthors=Catherine C. Fraser, Dierk O. Hoffmann |year=2006 |publisher=ABC-CLIO |location= |isbn=1-85109-738-4 |page=314 |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=YGgaLBLodH0C&pg=PA314&dq=%22Junge+Wilde%22&hl=en&ei=Jq_mTNzQAoH7lweXnJyTDA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=%22Junge%20Wilde%22&f=false }}</ref> and was only later used with reference to politics. At present, the term is used by German-language journalists to describe any group within a tradition that seeks to undermine established authority.{{Citation needed|date=November 2010}}
==Artistic Movement== In 1978, the Junge Wilde painting style arose the German speaking world in opposition to established [[Avant garde]], [[Minimal Art]] and [[Conceptual Art]]. It was linked to the similar [[Transavantguardia]] movement in Italy, USA ([[New-Image-Painting]]) and France ([[Figuration Libre]]). The Junge Wilde painted their expressive paintings in bright, intense colors and with quick, broad brushstrokes. They were sometimes called the '''Neue Wilde''' ([[:de:Neue Wilde]]).
===Influential Artist=== * Austria: [[Siegfried Anzinger]], [[Erwin Bohatsch]], [[Herbert Brandl]], [[Gunter Damisch]], [[Hubert Scheibl]], [[Hubert Schmalix]] * Berlin: [[Luciano Castelli]], [[Rainer Fetting]], [[Andreas Walther]], [[Helmut Middendorf]], [[Salomé (artist)|Salomé]], [[Bernd Zimmer]], [[Elvira Bach]], [[Peter Robert Keil]] * Cologne: [[Hans Peter Adamski]], [[Peter Bömmels]], [[Walter Dahn]], [[Jiri Georg Dokoupil]], [[Leiko Ikemura]], [[Gerard Kever]], [[Gerhard Naschberger]], [[Volker Tannert]], [[Elias Maria Reti]], [[Stefan Szczesny]] * Dresden [[A. R. Penck]] * Düsseldorf: [[Moritz Reichelt]], [[Joerg Immendorff]], [[Albert Oehlen]], [[Markus Oehlen]], [[Martin Kippenberger]], [[Markus Luepertz]], [[Werner Buettner]], [[Horst Gläsker]] * Switzerland: [[Martin Disler]]
==Later Usage== The term Junge Wilde began to be used by the media in the 1990s with reference to a certain group of politicians who bucked party leadership to make their names. It was first used with reference to the German [[Christian Democratic Union of Germany|CDU]] party (particularly against [[Helmut Kohl]]).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-5224370.html|title=Kohl Backs Critic in Key State Vote|last=Karacs|first=Imre|date=26 January 1998|work=International Herald Tribune {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}|accessdate=22 October 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-4944243.html|title=Defeat leaves Kohl's party in disarray|last=Karacs|first=Imre|date=1 October 1998|work=The Independent {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}|accessdate=22 October 2012}}</ref>
Since then the term has also been applied to members of other parties.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.dbwv.de/C12574E8003E04C8/Print/W28S7PMN559DSFADE|title="Junge Wilde" geben Gas|work=Deutscher BundeswehrVerband|accessdate=30 October 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.pnn.de/potsdam/142501/|title=Junge Wilde|last=Schicketanz|first=Sabine|work=Potsdamer Neuste Nachrichten|accessdate=30 October 2012}}</ref>
